evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

He suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3 and H8 document communication among crew and highlight a breakdown in effective coordination and warning signals, supporting the claim of observable communication/coordination breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in whether communication failures or procedural deviations were primary cause.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is observed and documented within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA aircraft during the hist_pair_engine_t2_interim phase on 12-25.

assumptions: The documented pushback event on 12-25 corresponds to the hist_pair_engine_t2_interim phase for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA aircraft.
No other unreported factors influenced the incident beyond those described in the evidence.
defeaters: If evidence showed effective communication and warnings were given but the incident still occurred, it might favor communication breakdown instead.
If environmental or mechanical factors were documented as primary causes, the procedural deviation claim would be weakened.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 documents the aircraft exceeding the TRP and hitting the blast barrier, indicating procedural deviation. H2 and H3 describe the pushback execution and seat swap, supporting observation of the deviation. H8 explains communication limitations, distinguishing procedural deviation from communication breakdown, favoring the procedural deviation hypothesis.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in communication effectiveness and possible unreported environmental or mechanical factors

children_spec.test_procedure: Check availability logs or records of procedure manuals or digital access for the ground crew during the pushback event

children_spec.statement: Ground crew had adequate training and knowledge of the pushback procedure
children_spec.test_procedure: Review training records and conduct interviews or assessments of the ground crew involved in the pushback

children_spec.statement: Required pushback equipment was available and operational during the pushback
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect maintenance and availability logs of pushback equipment used at the time of the event

children_spec.statement: Communication channels between the flight crew and ground crew were available and functioning during pushback
children_spec.test_procedure: Verify communication system logs and recordings for the pushback timeframe

node.statement: Crew failed to initiate or maintain communication protocols as required

assumptions: Communication protocols require active warnings and alerts among crew during pushback
Lack of warning implies failure to maintain communication protocols
defeaters: If evidence showed effective communication warnings or protocol adherence by crew
If the collision was caused by procedural deviation unrelated to communication

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8 indicates lack of warning from wingman or headset operator, supporting failure to maintain communication protocols; H1 and H2 show communication context but no effective protocol maintenance.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether communication protocols were formally required and fully documented

node.statement: Crew members were not reachable during critical phases of the flight

assumptions: Absence of warning implies lack of reachability or communication breakdown among crew.
defeaters: If evidence showed continuous, effective communication among crew during critical phases, or explicit warnings were given and acknowledged.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8 directly states that the tug instructor did not receive any warning from the wingman or headset operator, indicating crew members were not reachable during critical phases, supporting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in communication effectiveness and possible unreported informal communication

node.statement: Required pushback equipment was available and operational during the pushback

defeaters: Evidence showing the tug or pushback equipment was unavailable or malfunctioning would change the assessment.
Explicit statements confirming equipment availability and operational status would support the claim.
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence explicitly states that the required pushback equipment was available and operational during the pushback; the provided history focuses on crew actions and events but does not address equipment availability or operational status.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence

node.statement: Communication equipment was unavailable or malfunctioning

assumptions: Lack of warning implies communication equipment or signaling was unavailable or malfunctioning
defeaters: If evidence showed effective communication or signaling was received and acted upon
If hardware or equipment was confirmed fully functional and used properly

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8 directly states that the tug instructor did not receive any warning from the wingman or headset operator, indicating communication equipment or signaling was ineffective or unavailable, supporting the claim of communication equipment unavailability or malfunction.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether communication equipment malfunctioned or signaling methods were insufficient

node.statement: Ground crew had adequate training and knowledge of the pushback procedure

assumptions: The trainee driver's qualification and awareness imply adequate training and knowledge for the ground crew as a whole
No contradictory evidence about the instructor's training is present
defeaters: If evidence showed the trainee or instructor lacked training or knowledge of the pushback procedure
If communication failures or environmental deficiencies were primary causes rather than procedural deviation

quotes.exact_quote: Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H9 directly states the trainee driver was qualified and aware of the pushback procedure, supporting that ground crew had adequate training and knowledge.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit statement about the instructor's training; assumption that trainee's qualification implies adequate training for ground crew

node.statement: Pushback procedure documentation was accessible to the ground crew at the time of operation

defeaters: If evidence showed the documentation was physically present and accessible to the ground crew during the operation, this would change the assessment.
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence explicitly states that pushback procedure documentation was accessible to the ground crew at the time of operation (no direct or indirect mention in H1-H9).
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence

node.statement: Relevant environmental markings are physically present at the site

assumptions: Presence of TRP marking implies relevant environmental markings are physically present at the site.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were missing, obscured, or physically inadequate, or personnel were unaware of them, the claim would be supported.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 confirms the TRP marking is present and physically adequate; H9 confirms personnel were aware of the TRP; H8 indicates no marking deficiency but rather communication and procedural issues, thus contradicting the claim that relevant environmental markings were deficient.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct statement about physical condition or visibility of markings beyond presence; possible ambiguity in adequacy of visual signals for stopping.

node.statement: Communication channels between the flight crew and ground crew were available and functioning during pushback

defeaters: If evidence showed communication equipment malfunction or lack of communication attempts between flight and ground crew.
If reports indicated headset operator or wingman failed to communicate or were unavailable.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1 confirms communication channels were available and functioning; H9 shows personnel were trained and aware; H8 indicates no communication failure was reported, supporting the claim that communication channels were available and functioning during pushback.
outcome.uncertainty_source: None significant; evidence directly supports communication availability and function.

node.statement: Environmental markings are maintained and not obscured or damaged

assumptions: Assuming that the presence of clear TRP markings implies environmental markings are maintained and not obscured or damaged.
defeaters: If evidence showed obscured or damaged environmental markings or physical evidence of marking degradation, the conclusion might change.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 indicates clear and maintained TRP markings, and H8 highlights communication and alerting failures rather than marking deficiencies, favoring communication breakdown over environmental marking deficiency.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether markings were physically obscured or damaged; no direct evidence of marking condition provided.

node.statement: The mechanical/control failure in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_pair_engine_t2_interim context is resistant to common defeaters and alternative explanations.

defeaters: If evidence showed verified fault codes or repeat malfunctions indicating mechanical failure
If communication and procedural adherence were confirmed without issues

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.
After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H2, H3, H8, and H9 indicate communication and procedural issues rather than mechanical failure, favoring alternative explanations over mechanical/control failure. H4 and H7 do not support mechanical failure distinctly. Thus, the mechanical/control failure is not resistant to defeaters.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in cause due to overlapping procedural and communication factors

children_spec.statement: Communication devices were powered on and functional during the incident
children_spec.test_procedure: Check maintenance logs and device status reports to verify if communication devices were operational

children_spec.statement: Crew members were physically available and able to communicate during the incident
children_spec.test_procedure: Review crew duty rosters, position logs, and witness statements to confirm crew presence and readiness

children_spec.statement: Communication channels were not obstructed or overloaded during the incident
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze communication traffic logs and interference reports to determine channel availability and congestion

children_spec.statement: Crew members had access to necessary communication protocols and information during the incident
children_spec.test_procedure: Examine training records and communication protocol documentation to verify crew knowledge and access

node.statement: Crew members were physically available and able to communicate during the incident

assumptions: Physical presence and headset communication imply availability and ability to communicate.
defeaters: If evidence showed crew members were physically absent or unable to communicate, or if communication devices failed.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3 and H9 show crew members were physically present and communicating; H8 indicates communication signals were attempted but insufficient, supporting availability and ability to communicate during the incident.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Potential ambiguity in effectiveness of communication signals and whether all crew members were fully attentive.

node.statement: Communication channels were not obstructed or overloaded during the incident

defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and timely warnings were given preventing the incident.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1 and H3 show communication channels were active and personnel were positioned to communicate, but H8 states no warning was received, indicating communication was ineffective or obstructed, contradicting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether communication was effectively received despite channels being open
